Sx1.T1.caption:
Table 1: Complexity comparison of FedAvg and typical adaptive FL algorithms for finding an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary point.
Sample complexity denotes the number of calls to the First-order Oracle (IFO) by all worker nodes to reach an ε𝜀\varepsilon-stationary point. Communication complexity is defined as the total number of back-and-forth communication rounds between each worker node and the central server required to reach an ε𝜀\varepsilon-stationary point.
Sx1.T1.table:
Algorithm Reference Sample Communication Adaptivity
FedAvg (Yang, Fang, and Liu 2021) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right)
(Karimireddy et al. 2020b)
FedAdagrad (Reddi et al. 2020) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) √square-root\surd
FedYogi (Reddi et al. 2020) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) √square-root\surd
FedAdam (Reddi et al. 2020) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) √square-root\surd
FedAMS (Wang, Lin, and Chen 2022) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) O​(ϵ−4)𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O\left(\epsilon^{-4}\right) √square-root\surd
FAFED Our work O~​(ϵ−3)~𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ3\tilde{O}\left(\epsilon^{-3}\right) O~​(ϵ−2)~𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ2\tilde{O}\left(\epsilon^{-2}\right) √square-root\surd
references: In FL settings, Reddi et al. (2020) firstly propose federated versions of adaptive optimizers, including a class of adaptive FL methods, such as FedAdagrad, FedYogi, and FedAdam. These methods achieve the same sample cost and communication rounds as FedAvg when assuming the β1=0subscript𝛽10\beta_{1}=0. Chen, Li, and Li (2020) proposed Federated AMSGrad and achieves the same sample cost and communication rounds. MimeAdam is proposed in (Karimireddy et al. 2020a) but it requires the full local gradient in each communication round. More recently, FedAMS is proposed in (Wang, Lin, and Chen 2022) and it provides the completed proof and considers the gradient compression. But it doesn’t improve the convergence rate. Table 1 summarizes the details of typical adaptive FL algorithms.

Sx8.T2.caption: Table 2: Testing accuracy of different algorithms on Fashion-MNIST dataset for different heterogeneity settings.
Sx8.T2.table:
Algorithms       Accuracy
      FedAvg             0.8451
      SCAFFOLD       0.8496
      STEM       0.8562
      FedAdam       0.8586
      FedAMS       0.8697
      FAFED       0.8816
references: Here we provide partial results in image classification tasks. Figure 3 shows the results in the medium heterogeneity setting and Figure 4 shows the results in the high heterogeneity setting. Table 2 shows the performance of methods on the Fashion-MNIST testing datasets.

Sx8.T2.st1.caption: (a) Low heterogeneity
Sx8.T2.st1.table:
Algorithms       Accuracy
      FedAvg             0.8451
      SCAFFOLD       0.8496
      STEM       0.8562
      FedAdam       0.8586
      FedAMS       0.8697
      FAFED       0.8816
references: In FL settings, Reddi et al. (2020) firstly propose federated versions of adaptive optimizers, including a class of adaptive FL methods, such as FedAdagrad, FedYogi, and FedAdam. These methods achieve the same sample cost and communication rounds as FedAvg when assuming the β1=0subscript𝛽10\beta_{1}=0. Chen, Li, and Li (2020) proposed Federated AMSGrad and achieves the same sample cost and communication rounds. MimeAdam is proposed in (Karimireddy et al. 2020a) but it requires the full local gradient in each communication round. More recently, FedAMS is proposed in (Wang, Lin, and Chen 2022) and it provides the completed proof and considers the gradient compression. But it doesn’t improve the convergence rate. Table 1 summarizes the details of typical adaptive FL algorithms.

Finally, we focus on the performance on the testing datasets. In Tables (Seen in the supplementary mateirals), we show the testing accuracy of FAFED and that of other algorithms on the Fashion-MNIST dataset for different heterogeneity settings after training with the same epochs. Although, with the increasing data heterogeneity, model training becomes more difficult. FAFED performs well under all conditions. It shows the adaptive FL methods adapt well and our method (FAFED) has a good performance in different heterogeneity settings.

Here we provide partial results in image classification tasks. Figure 3 shows the results in the medium heterogeneity setting and Figure 4 shows the results in the high heterogeneity setting. Table 2 shows the performance of methods on the Fashion-MNIST testing datasets.
